metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page describing disclosure controls, which are UI components that reveal and hide information and functionality related to specific controls or views. The document covers best practices, disclosure triangles, disclosure buttons, platform considerations, and provides developer resources.

content.text: Disclosure controls reveal and hide information and functionality related to specific controls or views.

content.description: Interactive demonstration showing two states of a disclosure control. The illustration shows two rounded square buttons side by side. The left button labeled 'Collapsed' has an orange/coral background color (#FF6B4A approximately) with a white downward-pointing chevron arrow icon in the center. The right button labeled 'Expanded' has an orange/coral background color with a white upward-pointing chevron arrow icon in the center. The buttons appear to be UI control examples demonstrating the collapsed and expanded states of a disclosure button.
content.composition: Two square buttons arranged horizontally with equal spacing, labels below each button

iconDetails.collapsedIcon: Downward-pointing chevron (>) rotated to point down, white color, centered in button
iconDetails.expandedIcon: Upward-pointing chevron (<) rotated to point up, white color, centered in button

content.contextualRelevance: Visual demonstration of the two states of a disclosure button control, showing how the chevron direction indicates whether content is hidden (down arrow) or visible (up arrow)

content.text: Use a disclosure control to hide details until they're relevant. Place controls that people are most likely to use at the top of the disclosure hierarchy so they're always visible, with more advanced functionality hidden by default. This organization helps people quickly find the most essential information without overwhelming them with too many detailed options.

content.text: A disclosure triangle shows and hides information and functionality associated with a view or a list of items. For example, Keynote uses a disclosure triangle to show advanced options when exporting a presentation, and the Finder uses disclosure triangles to progressively reveal hierarchy when navigating a folder structure in list view.

content.description: A macOS-style folder list view showing three folders in collapsed state. Each folder row contains: a right-pointing disclosure triangle (gray chevron), a blue folder icon, and folder name text. The three folders are listed vertically as 'Folder 1', 'Folder 2', and 'Folder 3'. The disclosure triangles point to the right (inward from leading edge), indicating the folders are collapsed and their contents are hidden. The background is a light gray rounded rectangle container.
content.composition: Vertical list of three folder rows within a rounded rectangle container, each row aligned horizontally with disclosure triangle, folder icon, and text label
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates the appearance of disclosure triangles in a collapsed state within a folder hierarchy, illustrating how the triangle points inward (right) when content is hidden

content.text: A disclosure triangle points inward from the leading edge when its content is hidden and down when its content is visible. Clicking or tapping the disclosure triangle switches between these two states, and the view expands or collapses accordingly to accommodate the content.
Provide a descriptive label when using a disclosure triangle. Make sure your labels indicate what is disclosed or hidden, like "Advanced Options."

content.text: A disclosure button shows and hides functionality associated with a specific control. For example, the macOS Save sheet shows a disclosure button next to the Save As text field. When people click or tap this button, the Save dialog expands to give advanced navigation options for selecting an output location for their document.

A disclosure button points down when its content is hidden and up when its content is visible. Clicking or tapping the disclosure button switches between these two states, and the view expands or collapses accordingly to accommodate the content.

content.description: A demonstration image showing a disclosure button in its collapsed state. The image appears to show the same orange/coral colored square button with chevron icon as seen in the main demo image at the top, but displayed in context to illustrate the collapsed state specifically for disclosure buttons.
content.contextualRelevance: Illustrates the appearance of a disclosure button when its associated content is hidden (collapsed state)

content.text: Place a disclosure button near the content that it shows and hides. Establish a clear relationship between the control and the expanded choices that appear when a person clicks or taps a button.

formattedSegments.text: Place a disclosure button near the content that it shows and hides.

content.text: Use no more than one disclosure button in a single view. Multiple disclosure buttons add complexity and can be confusing.

content.text: No additional considerations for macOS. Not supported in tvOS or watchOS.
Disclosure controls are available in iOS, iPadOS, and visionOS with the SwiftUI DisclosureGroup view.

pages.pageSummary: Apple Human Interface Guidelines documentation page for Disclosure Controls. The page explains two types of disclosure controls: disclosure triangles (for showing/hiding hierarchical content like folder lists) and disclosure buttons (for showing/hiding functionality associated with specific controls). Includes visual examples, best practice guidelines, platform availability notes (supported on iOS, iPadOS, macOS, visionOS; not supported on tvOS or watchOS), and developer documentation links to SwiftUI DisclosureGroup and AppKit NSButton.BezelStyle APIs.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Guidelines for using disclosure controls to hide details until relevant, placing frequently-used controls at the top of hierarchy, and hiding advanced functionality by default.

sections.title: Disclosure triangles
sections.summary: Detailed explanation of disclosure triangles that show/hide information in views or lists. Describes visual behavior (points inward when collapsed, down when expanded), provides examples (Keynote export options, Finder list view), and emphasizes the need for descriptive labels.

sections.title: Disclosure buttons
sections.summary: Explanation of disclosure buttons that show/hide functionality for specific controls. Describes visual behavior (points down when collapsed, up when expanded), placement guidelines (near associated content), and limitation (no more than one per view).
